q: How can I determine if my vaginal discharge is normal?
a: Normal vaginal discharge is usually clear or white, has no strong or unpleasant smell, and is thick and sticky or slippery and wet.

q: What are the possible causes of abnormal vaginal discharge?
a: Abnormal vaginal discharge can be caused by bacterial vaginosis (if it smells fishy), thrush (if it is thick and white like cottage cheese), trichomoniasis (if it is green, yellow or frothy), chlamydia or gonorrhoea (if there is pelvic pain or bleeding), or genital herpes (if there are blisters or sores).

q: When should I see a doctor about my vaginal discharge?
a: You should see a GP or go to a sexual health clinic if your vaginal discharge changes in color, smell, or texture, if you produce more discharge than usual, if you feel itchy or sore, if you bleed between periods or after sex, if you experience pain when peeing, or if you have pain in the pelvic area.

q: What can sexual health clinics help with regarding abnormal discharge?
a: Sexual health clinics can help diagnose and treat problems with abnormal vaginal discharge. They often offer a walk-in service and can provide quicker test results than GP surgeries.

q: Can panty liners help with vaginal discharge?
a: Panty liners can help with heavy or excessive discharge or if there is concern about any smell. However, they should not be used all the time as they can cause irritation.

q: What precautions should I take to avoid irritation or dryness related to vaginal discharge?
a: To avoid irritation, soreness, or dryness, gently wash the skin around your vagina with plain water. Avoid using perfumed or non-perfumed soaps or gels, deodorants, scented hygiene wipes, or washing inside your vagina (douching).

q: Can vaginal discharge be prevented?
a: Vaginal discharge cannot be prevented, as it is a normal bodily function that helps keep the vagina clean and protected against infection.

q: Does the amount of vaginal discharge vary?
a: Yes, the amount of vaginal discharge can vary. It is normal to have heavier discharge during pregnancy, if you are sexually active, or if you are using birth control. It is also common to have slippery and wet discharge for a few days between periods when ovulating.

q: Can changes in vaginal discharge indicate an infection?
a: Yes, changes in vaginal discharge such as smell, color, or texture can be a sign of an infection. However, it is important not to self-diagnose and to see a GP if you are worried.

q: What should I do if I experience pelvic pain or bleeding along with vaginal discharge?
a: If you experience pelvic pain or bleeding along with abnormal vaginal discharge, it could be a sign of chlamydia or gonorrhoea. It is important to see a GP or go to a sexual health clinic for further evaluation and possible testing.

q: What is vaginal discharge?
a: Vaginal discharge is a fluid or mucus that keeps the vagina clean and moist, and protects it from infection.
